Pluely: The Open Source AI Assistant That's 27x Lighter Than Cluely

Dec 31, 2025
Vibe Sparking

In the world of AI meeting assistants, one name has been making waves: Cluely. Marketed as the “#1 Undetectable AI for Meetings,” Cluely raised $15M in funding to build a stealth AI assistant that helps you during meetings, interviews, and conversations—completely invisibly.

But what if you want the same powerful features without the proprietary lock-in, the hefty price tag, or the 270MB application size?

Enter Pluely—the open-source alternative that’s just 10MB, privacy-first, and built for the community.

Why Pluely Matters

Section titled “Why Pluely Matters”

Pluely represents a growing movement in the AI space: open-source, privacy-first alternatives to commercial AI tools. As developers and users become increasingly concerned about data privacy, vendor lock-in, and bloated applications, projects like Pluely offer a compelling alternative.

The Numbers Don’t Lie

Section titled “The Numbers Don’t Lie”
FeaturePluely (Open Source)Cluely (Proprietary)
App Size~10MB~270MB
Size Difference27x smallerBaseline
Compute Usage50% less CPU/RAMHeavy resource usage
Startup Time<100msSeveral seconds
Privacy100% local with your LLMData sent to servers
CostFree & Open SourceCommercial pricing
LicenseGPL-3.0Proprietary

Source: Pluely GitHub

Built with Tauri: Why It Matters

Section titled “Built with Tauri: Why It Matters”

Pluely is built with Tauri, a modern framework for building desktop applications using web technologies. This architectural choice is significant:

Tauri vs Electron Performance

Section titled “Tauri vs Electron Performance”

Based on 2024-2025 benchmarks:

  • Memory Usage: Tauri uses 50-58% less memory than Electron equivalents
  • Startup Time: Tauri apps launch in under 500ms vs ~4 seconds for Electron
  • Bundle Size: Tauri produces substantially smaller bundles by using native OS webview components instead of bundling Chromium

Sources:

  • Tauri vs Electron Comparison
  • Tauri vs Electron 2025 Comparison

Why This Matters for Users

Section titled “Why This Matters for Users”

For an AI assistant that needs to run constantly in the background:

  1. Less battery drain on laptops
  2. More resources available for other applications
  3. Instant startup when you need quick answers
  4. Smaller downloads and updates

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

1. Invisibility Mode

Section titled “1. Invisibility Mode”

Pluely’s signature feature is its translucent overlay window that sits above all other applications. This makes it:

  • Invisible in video calls (Zoom, Google Meet, Teams, Slack)
  • Undetectable in screen shares and recordings
  • Screenshot-proof by design
  • Perfectly stealthy during interviews and presentations

2. Real-Time Audio Capture

Section titled “2. Real-Time Audio Capture”

The system audio capture feature allows you to:

  • Record audio directly from your computer’s output
  • Transcribe meetings in real-time
  • Use voice activity detection for efficient processing

3. Multi-Provider AI Support

Section titled “3. Multi-Provider AI Support”

Unlike many alternatives that lock you into one provider, Pluely supports:

Pre-configured Providers:

  • OpenAI (GPT models)
  • Anthropic (Claude)
  • Google (Gemini)
  • xAI (Grok)
  • Mistral AI
  • Cohere
  • Perplexity
  • Groq
  • Ollama (local models)

Custom Providers: Add any LLM provider using curl commands with full flexibility for authentication, streaming, and response parsing.

4. Voice Input & Screenshots

Section titled “4. Voice Input & Screenshots”
  • Voice Input: Record and convert speech to text using multiple STT providers (OpenAI Whisper, ElevenLabs, Groq, etc.)
  • Screenshot Capture: Full screen or selection mode with manual or automatic AI processing
  • File Attachments: Attach documents, images, and code files for AI analysis

Privacy-First Architecture

Section titled “Privacy-First Architecture”

In an era where data privacy is paramount, Pluely takes a fundamentally different approach:

Local Data Storage

Section titled “Local Data Storage”
  • Conversations: Stored locally in SQLite on your device
  • Settings: Stored in browser localStorage, never transmitted
  • Credentials: Encrypted secure storage for API keys
  • No Telemetry: Zero analytics, usage tracking, or data collection

Direct API Connections

Section titled “Direct API Connections”

Pluely makes API calls directly from your device to your chosen AI provider:

  • No proxy servers
  • No middleware
  • No data collection
  • Verifiable via browser developer tools

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”

Pluely shines in scenarios where you need AI assistance without detection:

  1. Job Interviews: Get real-time information and suggestions
  2. Sales Calls: Access product details instantly while maintaining professionalism
  3. Technical Meetings: Reference documentation without breaking flow
  4. Educational Presentations: Learning assistance that’s invisible to your audience
  5. Design Reviews: Analyze screenshots and get suggestions
  6. Live Coding: Debug code with syntax help in stealth mode

Installation and Usage

Section titled “Installation and Usage”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • Node.js (v18 or higher)
  • Rust (latest stable)
  • npm or yarn
  • Tauri prerequisites for your platform

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

This creates platform-specific installers:

  • macOS: .dmg
  • Windows: .msi, .exe
  • Linux: .deb, .rpm, .AppImage

The Competitive Landscape

Section titled “The Competitive Landscape”

Pluely isn’t the only player in the invisible AI assistant space. Other alternatives include:

  • LockedInAI: Desktop app for stealth interview assistance
  • Final Round AI: Coaching for job interviews with video call integration
  • Beyz AI: Stealth mode for technical and behavioral questions

However, Pluely distinguishes itself through:

  • Open source transparency (GPL-3.0 license)
  • Extremely small footprint (10MB vs competitors’ 100MB+)
  • Multi-provider flexibility (not locked into one AI service)
  • Active development with regular releases

Sources:

  • Cluely Alternatives 2025
  • Cluely Alternatives - Fellow

Ethical Considerations

Section titled “Ethical Considerations”

It’s worth addressing the elephant in the room: the ethics of invisible AI assistance.

Several sources note these tools can be used for “cheating in live conversations,” which raises legitimate concerns about:

  • Academic integrity during online exams
  • Professional authenticity in job interviews
  • Fairness in competitive scenarios

Pluely and similar tools are powerful, and with power comes responsibility. The open-source nature of Pluely at least provides transparency—you can inspect exactly what the software does, unlike proprietary black-box alternatives.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Pluely represents an important trend in AI development: the move toward transparent, privacy-first, open-source alternatives to commercial offerings. Its 27x smaller footprint than Cluely demonstrates that you don’t need bloated software to deliver powerful features.

Whether you choose to use Pluely or not, its existence pushes the industry toward:

  • Better privacy practices
  • More efficient software architecture
  • Greater user control
  • Open standards over lock-in

The AI assistant wars are just getting started, and open-source projects like Pluely are ensuring users have a choice.

Links

Section titled “Links”
  • Pluely Website: pluely.com
  • GitHub Repository: iamsrikanthnani/pluely
  • Cluely (Original): cluely.com
  • Tauri Framework: tauri.app

Superagent: AI Guardrails for Secure and Compliant Agents

Dec 31, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Superagent: AI Guardrails for Secure and Compliant Agents

Section titled “Superagent: AI Guardrails for Secure and Compliant Agents”

As AI agents and chatbots become integral to business operations, ensuring their security and compliance has never been more critical. Enter Superagent – an open-source guardrail system that provides purpose-trained models to secure AI applications in real-time.

The Challenge of AI Safety

Section titled “The Challenge of AI Safety”

Building production AI applications introduces unique security challenges:

  • Prompt injection attacks that can hijack agent behavior
  • Hallucinations that spread misinformation
  • Data leaks through inadvertent PII/PHI exposure
  • Compliance violations across regulatory frameworks
  • Tool abuse where agents execute unauthorized actions

Traditional approaches using general-purpose LLMs for safety checks introduce latency and lack the precision needed for production environments.

What is Superagent?

Section titled “What is Superagent?”

Superagent provides three purpose-trained models that work together to secure AI applications:

Guard

Section titled “Guard”

Threat Detection with 98% Accuracy

Guard detects and blocks unsafe inputs before they reach your models:

  • Prompt injections and jailbreak attempts
  • Malicious tool calls
  • Backdoors and adversarial inputs
  • Unsafe content generation

According to Superagent’s benchmarks, Guard outperforms GPT-4, Gemini 2.5 Pro, and other frontier models in threat detection – without the latency penalty of running a full LLM for safety checks.

Verify

Section titled “Verify”

Output Validation and Grounding

Verify grounds and validates model outputs against enterprise sources:

  • Fact-checking against internal documents
  • Policy compliance verification
  • Consistency validation
  • Hallucination prevention

Every generation is validated before reaching users, ensuring factual accuracy and policy alignment.

Redact

Section titled “Redact”

Real-Time Data Protection

Redact removes sensitive data from text and documents:

  • PII (Personally Identifiable Information)
  • PHI (Protected Health Information)
  • API keys and secrets
  • Custom sensitive patterns

Privacy and compliance are maintained across AI inputs and outputs without manual review.

Architecture and Performance

Section titled “Architecture and Performance”

Low-Latency Design

Section titled “Low-Latency Design”

Unlike general-purpose LLMs used for safety, Superagent’s models are purpose-trained for specific security tasks, enabling:

  • Sub-millisecond response times for Guard checks
  • Minimal overhead on AI workflows
  • High-throughput processing for enterprise scale

Open Source Foundation

Section titled “Open Source Foundation”

Superagent is MIT-licensed with 10K+ GitHub stars, providing:

  • Full transparency in safety logic
  • Community-driven improvements
  • Self-hosting capabilities
  • No vendor lock-in

Integration Options

Section titled “Integration Options”

REST API

Section titled “REST API”

The simplest integration – send any payload and receive guarded results:

Section titled “Python SDK”

Section titled “TypeScript SDK”

Section titled “CLI Tool”

Section titled “MCP Server”

Compliance Coverage

Section titled “Compliance Coverage”

Superagent maps to major compliance frameworks:

FrameworkCoverage
EU AI ActRisk classification, requirements
ISO/IEC 42001AI management system standards
NIST AI RMFRisk management framework
GDPRData protection and privacy
SOC 2Security controls
HIPAAHealthcare data protection

This mapping helps organizations build audit trails and ensure regulatory alignment across all AI models.

Comparison with Alternatives

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Layer Your Defenses – Use Guard for inputs, Verify for outputs, and Redact for logging
  2. Context Matters – Provide relevant context for better accuracy
  3. Custom Rules – Define organization-specific threat patterns
  4. Monitor False Positives – Continuously tune based on production data
  5. Version Your Policies – Track compliance requirements over time

Resources

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Superagent fills a critical gap in the AI stack – production-grade safety infrastructure that doesn’t compromise on performance. Whether you’re building customer-facing chatbots, internal AI workflows, or autonomous agents, Superagent provides the guardrails needed to ship with confidence.

The combination of high accuracy (98%), low latency, open-source transparency, and comprehensive compliance coverage makes Superagent a compelling choice for teams serious about AI safety.

Guard. Verify. Redact. – Your AI applications deserve nothing less.

DeepTutor: AI-Powered Personalized Learning Assistant Based on Multi-Agent Architecture

DeepTutor: AI-Powered Personalized Learning Assistant Based on Multi-Agent Architecture

Section titled “DeepTutor: AI-Powered Personalized Learning Assistant Based on Multi-Agent Architecture”

In today’s rapidly evolving landscape of AI-driven education, traditional one-size-fits-all tutoring approaches are giving way to intelligent, adaptive learning systems. Allow me to introduce DeepTutor — an open-source AI personalized learning assistant from the Data Intelligence Lab at The University of Hong Kong (HKUDS), which combines multi-agent architecture with advanced RAG capabilities to deliver a comprehensive learning experience.

What is DeepTutor?

Section titled “What is DeepTutor?”

DeepTutor is a full-stack AI learning platform that revolutionizes how students and researchers interact with educational content. Open-sourced under the AGPL-3.0 license, it offers seven interconnected modules designed to support the entire learning lifecycle, from knowledge acquisition to research ideation.

Core Advantage: DeepTutor employs a dual-loop reasoning architecture that separates the investigation process from problem solving, enabling deeper analysis and more accurate solutions compared to single-turn AI tutors.

Core Features Overview

Section titled “Core Features Overview”
FeatureDescription
Smart Knowledge BaseUpload textbooks, papers, manuals to build your own AI knowledge repository
Multi-Agent Problem SolvingDual-loop architecture integrating RAG, web search, paper search, code execution
Knowledge SimplificationTransform complex concepts into visual diagrams and step-by-step explanations
Personalized Q&AContext-aware conversations that adapt to learning progress
Intelligent Question GenerationGenerate customized quizzes and assessments
Real Exam SimulationClone exam styles for authentic practice experiences
In-Depth Research & Literature ReviewSystematic analysis and cross-domain knowledge synthesis
Novel Insight DiscoveryIdentify knowledge gaps and research directions

System Architecture

Section titled “System Architecture”

DeepTutor adopts a modern full-stack design based on agent architecture:

Module Details

Section titled “Module Details”

1. Smart Solver — Dual-Loop Problem Solving

Section titled “1. Smart Solver — Dual-Loop Problem Solving”

The Smart Solver employs a sophisticated dual-loop architecture that separates analysis from solving:

Analysis Loop

  • InvestigateAgent: Collects context and relevant materials
  • NoteAgent: Compresses findings into structured notes

Solve Loop

  • PlanAgent: Creates step-by-step solution plans
  • ManagerAgent: Coordinates overall execution
  • SolveAgent: Generates solutions using tools
  • CheckAgent: Verifies answers
  • FormatAgent: Formats final output

Core Features:

FeatureDescription
Real-time StreamingWebSocket displays reasoning process in real time
Multi-Tool IntegrationRAG (naive/hybrid), web search, code execution
Citation ManagementStructured citations with reference tracking
Persistent MemoryJSON file saves context

2. Question Generator — Custom & Mimic Modes

Section titled “2. Question Generator — Custom & Mimic Modes”

DeepTutor supports two powerful question generation approaches:

Custom Mode

  • Generate questions from knowledge base
  • Specify difficulty, type, and quantity
  • Auto-verification with no refusal logic

Mimic Mode

  • Upload reference exam PDFs
  • MinerU parses and extracts structure
  • Generate questions matching original style

3. Guided Learning — Interactive Knowledge Visualization

Section titled “3. Guided Learning — Interactive Knowledge Visualization”

Transform static learning materials into interactive experiences:

AgentResponsibility
LocateAgentIdentify 3-5 progressive knowledge points
InteractiveAgentConvert concepts into visual HTML pages
ChatAgentProvide contextual Q&A for each topic
SummaryAgentGenerate learning summary upon completion

Workflow:

  1. Select a notebook containing learning records
  2. System generates progressive learning paths
  3. Interactive visualization for each concept
  4. Contextual Q&A
  5. Receive session summary

4. Deep Research — DR-in-KG System

Section titled “4. Deep Research — DR-in-KG System”

The DR-in-KG (Deep Research in Knowledge Graph) module achieves systematic research through dynamic topic queues:

Preset Modes:

  • quick: 1-2 subtopics, 1-2 iterations
  • medium: 5 subtopics, 4 iterations
  • deep: 8 subtopics, 7 iterations
  • auto: Agent autonomously determines depth

5. Collaborative Writing — Interactive AI Writing Assistant

Section titled “5. Collaborative Writing — Interactive AI Writing Assistant”

A feature-rich Markdown editor equipped with AI enhancements:

FeatureDescription
EditAgentRewrite, shorten, expand (optional context)
Auto-AnnotationAutomatically identify key content
NarratorAgentTTS generation with multiple voice options
Multi-Format ExportMarkdown, PDF export

6. Automatic Idea Generation — Research Ideation

Section titled “6. Automatic Idea Generation — Research Ideation”

Extract knowledge points from learning materials and generate research insights:

7. Knowledge Base & Notebooks

Section titled “7. Knowledge Base & Notebooks”

Knowledge Base Management:

  • Upload PDF, Markdown, TXT documents
  • Hybrid RAG + Knowledge Graph indexing
  • Incremental document addition
  • Supports text-embedding-3-large (3072 dimensions)

Personal Notebooks:

  • Multi-notebook management
  • Unified record storage across modules
  • Categorize by type and knowledge base
  • Custom colors and icons

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: What if port 8001 is already in use? A: Edit config/main.yaml and change server.backend_port to another port.

Q: Can I add documents to an existing knowledge base? A: Yes! Use incremental addition: python -m src.knowledge.add_documents <kb_name> --docs <new_file.pdf>

Q: How do I properly stop the service? A: Press Ctrl+C. If the port remains occupied, use lsof -i :8001 to find and terminate the process.

Q: Does it support offline operation? A: After knowledge base construction, core RAG functions can run offline. Web search and paper search require internet connection.

  4. Seven Integrated Modules covering the complete learning lifecycle

DeepTutor provides a powerful, scalable personalized learning platform for students, educators, and researchers.

Chat UI Swift: A SwiftUI Chat Application Showcasing AnyLanguageModel and Swift-HuggingFace

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Chat UI Swift: A SwiftUI Chat Application Showcasing AnyLanguageModel and Swift-HuggingFace

Section titled “Chat UI Swift: A SwiftUI Chat Application Showcasing AnyLanguageModel and Swift-HuggingFace”

Building AI-powered chat applications on Apple platforms has traditionally required navigating multiple SDKs, APIs, and authentication flows. mattt/chat-ui-swift simplifies this landscape with a beautiful SwiftUI reference implementation that demonstrates how to integrate multiple language model providers through a unified API.

What is Chat UI Swift?

Section titled “What is Chat UI Swift?”

Chat UI Swift is a SwiftUI chat application created by Mattt Thompson, the legendary developer behind AFNetworking and NSHipster. It serves as a demonstration app for two powerful Swift libraries:

  1. AnyLanguageModel - A drop-in replacement for Apple’s Foundation Models framework with support for custom language model providers
  2. swift-huggingface - A Swift client for the Hugging Face API

GitHub Repository: mattt/chat-ui-swift Author: Mattt Thompson License: MIT

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

Currently Supported

Section titled “Currently Supported”
  • Apple Intelligence - Native integration with Apple Foundation Models (macOS 26+) for on-device AI
  • Hugging Face Integration - Connect to Hugging Face with OAuth 2.0 authentication
  • Streaming Responses - Real-time streaming of AI responses for a responsive user experience
  • Chat Persistence - Save and manage multiple conversations

Planned Features

Section titled “Planned Features”
  • MLX Model Support - Download and run models locally using MLX
  • CoreML Integration - Support for CoreML-optimized models
  • GGUF Format Support - Load GGUF models from Hugging Face Hub
  • Model Downloads - Browse and download models directly from Hugging Face
  • BYOK (Bring Your Own Key) - Support for OpenAI, Anthropic, and other inference providers

Understanding AnyLanguageModel

Section titled “Understanding AnyLanguageModel”

The real power behind chat-ui-swift is AnyLanguageModel, a Swift package that provides a unified API for accessing multiple language model providers.

Why AnyLanguageModel Matters

Section titled “Why AnyLanguageModel Matters”

Traditionally, integrating different LLM providers required learning different SDKs and APIs:

With AnyLanguageModel, you use a single API:

OpenAICloudChat Completions & Responses APIs

Swift 6.1 Package Traits

Section titled “Swift 6.1 Package Traits”

AnyLanguageModel leverages Swift 6.1 package traits to conditionally include heavy dependencies. This means you only compile the backends you actually use:

This results in:

  • Smaller binary sizes - Unused backends aren’t compiled
  • Faster build times - Less code to compile
  • Flexible deployment - Add/remove providers as needed

Section titled “Using Hugging Face Models”

  2. Click the sign-in button in the sidebar
  3. Authenticate with your Hugging Face account
  4. Select a Hugging Face model from the model picker
  5. Start chatting!

The app uses OAuth 2.0 to securely authenticate with Hugging Face. Your access token is stored in the Keychain and automatically refreshed.

Security Best Practices

Section titled “Security Best Practices”

The AnyLanguageModel documentation includes important guidance on API credential security:

Never Hardcode API Keys

Section titled “Never Hardcode API Keys”

Malicious actors can reverse-engineer your app binary or observe network traffic to extract embedded credentials.

Recommended Approaches

Section titled “Recommended Approaches”
  1. Bring Your Own Key (BYO) - Users provide their own keys, stored in Keychain
  2. Proxy Server - Route requests through your authenticated service

Important: Apple App Review has often rejected apps using the BYOK model. Consider using a proxy server for production apps.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Chat UI Swift is more than a demo app—it’s a reference implementation for building AI-powered chat applications on Apple platforms. By leveraging AnyLanguageModel and swift-huggingface, developers can:

  • Use a unified API for multiple LLM providers
  • Switch providers without changing application code
  • Integrate Apple Intelligence alongside cloud models
  • Authenticate with Hugging Face via OAuth
  • Build beautiful SwiftUI chat interfaces

The project exemplifies modern Swift development practices: protocol-oriented design, async/await concurrency, and careful attention to security.

Claude Usage Tracker: Native macOS Menu Bar App for Real-Time Claude AI Usage Monitoring

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Claude Usage Tracker: Native macOS Menu Bar App for Real-Time Claude AI Usage Monitoring

Section titled “Claude Usage Tracker: Native macOS Menu Bar App for Real-Time Claude AI Usage Monitoring”

For Claude AI power users, keeping track of usage limits is crucial—especially when working with the premium Opus model. Claude Usage Tracker is a beautifully crafted, native macOS menu bar application that provides real-time monitoring of your Claude AI usage limits, built entirely with Swift and SwiftUI.

Official Apple code signed • macOS 14.0+ • ~3 MB • MIT License

What is Claude Usage Tracker?

Section titled “What is Claude Usage Tracker?”

Claude Usage Tracker is a lightweight, native macOS menu bar application that provides real-time monitoring of your Claude AI usage limits. Unlike web-based solutions, this app runs natively on your Mac with:

  • Real-Time Monitoring: Track session (5-hour), weekly, and API console usage
  • Official Apple Code Signing: No security warnings—installs like any normal Mac app
  • Automatic Updates: Built-in Sparkle-powered update system
  • Developer Integration: Terminal statusline for Claude Code users
  • Privacy-First: Local storage, no telemetry, no cloud sync

GitHub Repository: hamed-elfayome/Claude-Usage-Tracker Author: Hamed Elfayome License: MIT Stars: 147+ | Install: brew install --cask claude-usage-tracker

What’s New in v2.0.0

Section titled “What’s New in v2.0.0”

The December 2024 v2.0.0 release was a major milestone that transformed the app from a great utility into a professional-grade macOS application:

Getting Started

Section titled “Getting Started”

1. Extract Your Session Key

Section titled “1. Extract Your Session Key”

The app needs your Claude AI session key for authentication:

  1. Open claude.ai and log in
  2. Open Developer Tools (Chrome/Edge: F12 or Cmd+Option+I)
  3. Navigate to Application → Cookies → https://claude.ai
  4. Find sessionKey cookie (starts with sk-ant-sid01-)
  5. Copy the entire value

2. First-Time Setup

Section titled “2. First-Time Setup”
  1. Launch Claude Usage Tracker
  2. The Welcome Wizard appears automatically
  3. Paste your session key and click “Validate”
  4. Wait for confirmation (green checkmark)
  5. Click “Done”

The menu bar icon now shows your live usage statistics!

ClaudeCode Workflow Studio: Visual Automation Editor for AI Workflows

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

ClaudeCode Workflow Studio: Visual Automation Editor for AI Workflows

Section titled “ClaudeCode Workflow Studio: Visual Automation Editor for AI Workflows”

Claude Code, Anthropic’s official CLI tool for AI-assisted development, has a powerful automation system through its .claude configuration files. However, creating complex workflows with multiple sub-agents, conditional branching, and user interactions requires editing markdown and YAML files manually. ClaudeCode Workflow Studio (cc-wf-studio) by breaking-brake brings a visual, drag-and-drop editor to VSCode, making workflow creation intuitive and accessible.

What is ClaudeCode Workflow Studio?

Section titled “What is ClaudeCode Workflow Studio?”

ClaudeCode Workflow Studio is a VSCode extension that provides a visual workflow editor for Claude Code. It allows you to:

  • Design workflows visually - Drag and drop nodes onto a canvas
  • Configure without code - Set up sub-agents, skills, and MCP tools through a UI
  • Export with one click - Generate .claude/agents/ and .claude/commands/ files automatically
  • Collaborate with your team - Share workflows via Slack with preview cards

GitHub Repository: breaking-brake/cc-wf-studio VSCode Marketplace: Open VSX License: AGPL-3.0-or-later Version: 3.9.1 (as of December 2025)

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Visual Workflow Editor

Section titled “1. Visual Workflow Editor”

The core of cc-wf-studio is its drag-and-drop canvas. Instead of writing markdown and YAML, you visually connect nodes to define workflow logic:

  • Prompt Nodes - Define reusable prompt templates with {{variable}} substitution
  • Sub-Agent Nodes - Configure autonomous AI agents with custom system prompts and tool permissions
  • Skill Nodes - Integrate Claude Code Skills from personal or project directories
  • MCP Nodes - Connect to Model Context Protocol tools for external integrations
  • Control Flow Nodes - IfElse (binary branching), Switch (multi-way branching), AskUserQuestion (user decisions)

2. AI-Assisted Workflow Refinement

Section titled “2. AI-Assisted Workflow Refinement”

One of the standout features is AI-assisted refinement. Instead of generating workflows from scratch once, you can iteratively improve them through conversation:

  1. Click the “Edit with AI” button (✨ sparkle icon)
  2. Describe your changes in natural language (max 2000 characters)
  3. The AI modifies your workflow incrementally, preserving existing work
  4. Repeat until satisfied

This conversational approach builds workflows through multiple rounds of feedback, with the AI maintaining conversation history and applying changes incrementally.

Example prompts:

  • “Add a Sub-Agent node that validates the input data”
  • “Connect the error handler to a logging Sub-Agent”
  • “Change the AskUserQuestion node to have 3 options: High, Medium, Low”

3. One-Click Export

Section titled “3. One-Click Export”

When your workflow is ready, click Export to generate:

  • .claude/agents/*.md - Sub-Agent definitions with system prompts and tool configurations
  • .claude/commands/*.md - SlashCommand definitions that execute the entire workflow

The exported files are ready to use immediately with Claude Code CLI. No manual editing required.

4. Slack Workflow Sharing (Beta)

Section titled “4. Slack Workflow Sharing (Beta)”

For teams, cc-wf-studio offers Slack integration:

  • Export workflows to Slack channels with preview cards
  • One-click import links for team members
  • Seamless collaboration without leaving your chat workspace

Quick Start Guide

Section titled “Quick Start Guide”

1. Open the Editor

Section titled “1. Open the Editor”
  • Press Ctrl+Shift+P / Cmd+Shift+P
  • Type “Claude Code Workflow Studio: Open Editor”
  • Press Enter

First-time users get an interactive onboarding tour (available in English, Japanese, Korean, Simplified Chinese, and Traditional Chinese).

2. Create Your Workflow

Section titled “2. Create Your Workflow”

The left palette is organized into sections:

  • Basic Nodes: Prompt (templates), Sub-Agent (AI tasks)
  • Control Flow: IfElse (binary branching), Switch (multi-way branching), AskUserQuestion (user decisions)
  • Integration: Skill (Claude Code Skills), MCP (external tools)

Steps:

  1. Drag nodes from the palette onto the canvas
  2. Click a node to edit its properties in the right panel
  3. Connect nodes by dragging from output ports (right) to input ports (left)
  4. Configure node-specific settings (prompts, variables, conditions)

3. Save & Export

Section titled “3. Save & Export”
  • Enter a workflow name in the toolbar
  • Click Save to store as JSON in .vscode/workflows/
  • Click Export to generate .claude files

Node Types Deep Dive

Section titled “Node Types Deep Dive”

Prompt Nodes

Section titled “Prompt Nodes”

Define reusable prompt templates with template variables:

Variables are automatically detected and validated. At runtime, values are dynamically substituted.

Sub-Agent Nodes

Section titled “Sub-Agent Nodes”

Configure autonomous AI agents with:

  • System Prompt - Custom instructions for the agent
  • Tool Permissions - Choose which tools the agent can access (Read, Write, Bash, etc.)
  • Model Selection - Sonnet (balanced), Opus (complex tasks), Haiku (speed)

Skill Nodes

Section titled “Skill Nodes”

Integrate Claude Code Skills into your workflows:

  • Personal Skills - From ~/.claude/skills/ for individual use
  • Project Skills - From .claude/skills/ for team collaboration
  • Create New Skills - Build skills directly from the visual editor with a guided form
  • Browse & Select - Interactive skill browser with descriptions

MCP Nodes

Section titled “MCP Nodes”

Integrate Model Context Protocol tools:

  1. Select an MCP server from the dropdown (configured in Claude Code)
  2. Browse available tools or use search to filter
  3. Configure parameters with dynamic form generation based on tool schemas
  4. Real-time validation with error messages

Prerequisites: MCP servers must be configured in Claude Code settings first.

Control Flow Nodes

Section titled “Control Flow Nodes”

IfElse Node

Section titled “IfElse Node”

Fixed 2-way branching for binary conditions (True/False, Yes/No, Success/Error).

Switch Node

Section titled “Switch Node”

Variable multi-way branching (2-N branches) with dynamic case management. Ideal for complex routing logic.

Usage Examples

Section titled “Usage Examples”

Example 1: Document Analysis Workflow

Section titled “Example 1: Document Analysis Workflow”
  1. Upload Document Prompt - Asks user for file path
  2. PDF Extractor Skill (Personal) - Extracts text from PDF files
  3. Ask User - “Processing type?” → Summarize / Translate / Analyze
  4. Document Processor Skill (Project) - Team-shared processing logic
  5. Format Results Sub-Agent - Creates final output

Example 2: Code Quality Scanner

Section titled “Example 2: Code Quality Scanner”
  1. Code Scanner Sub-Agent - Identifies issues
  2. Ask User - “Priority level?” → Critical Only / All Issues
  3. Filter Results Sub-Agent
  4. Generate Fix Suggestions Sub-Agent

Example 3: Web Automation with Playwright

Section titled “Example 3: Web Automation with Playwright”
  1. Input URL Prompt - Asks user for target website
  2. Playwright Navigate MCP Tool - Opens browser and navigates to URL
  3. Ask User - “Action type?” → Screenshot / Extract Text / Click Element
  4. Playwright Action MCP Tool - Performs the selected browser action
  5. Process Results Sub-Agent - Analyzes and formats output

Internationalization

Section titled “Internationalization”

The Visual Editor UI and all exported files automatically adapt to your VSCode display language setting (vscode.env.language). Supported languages:

  • English (default)
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Simplified Chinese (zh-CN)
  • Traditional Chinese (zh-TW/zh-HK)

This ensures both the editing experience and generated workflows are accessible for international teams.

Limitations

Section titled “Limitations”
  • Maximum 50 nodes per workflow
  • AI processing timeout (default 90 seconds, configurable: 30s-5min)
  • Request limited to 2000 characters for AI refinement
  • Conversation history stored only during active session
  • Requires active Claude Code CLI installation

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

Workflow won’t save

  • Ensure workflow name contains only letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores
  • Check all required fields are filled
  • Look for error messages in VSCode notifications

Export fails

  • Verify all nodes have valid configurations
  • Ensure node names are unique
  • Check write permissions for .claude directory

Can’t load workflow

  • Click refresh button (↻) to update the list
  • Verify file exists in .vscode/workflows/
  • Check JSON file isn’t corrupted

Introduction: From Video Frames to Hand-Drawn Stories

Section titled “Introduction: From Video Frames to Hand-Drawn Stories”

Content creators on platforms like Bilibili and Xiaohongshu (Little Red Book) face a common challenge: how to transform video highlights into engaging, shareable content that stands out. Traditional video editing is time-consuming, and converting video moments into stylized content typically requires artistic skills or expensive tools.

ClipSketch AI by RanFeng offers an innovative solution. This open-source web application leverages Google Gemini’s multimodal AI to automatically convert video moments into beautiful hand-drawn storyboard illustrations, complete with AI-generated social media captions.

What is ClipSketch AI?

Section titled “What is ClipSketch AI?”

ClipSketch AI is an AI-powered content creation workstation designed specifically for video creators, social media operators, and remix enthusiasts. It goes beyond simple video playback by integrating frame-level marking with Google Gemini’s latest multimodal large models to generate hand-drawn style storyboards and viral social media copy.

  • Utilities: JSZip for packaging, Canvas API for screenshots

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

1. Powerful Video Acquisition

Section titled “1. Powerful Video Acquisition”

ClipSketch AI supports direct importing from popular Chinese social platforms:

  • Multi-Source Import: Parse sharing links from Bilibili and Xiaohongshu (supports short links and mixed text)
  • HD Playback: Adaptive layout optimization for vertical (9:16) and widescreen videos
  • Precise Control: Keyboard shortcuts (Space for play/pause, arrow keys for frame-by-frame or smart stepping)

2. Frame-Level Marking System

Section titled “2. Frame-Level Marking System”

The built-in marking system provides professional-grade precision:

  • Millisecond Recording: Capture every highlight moment with precision
  • Shortcut Tagging: Press T key to quickly mark frames
  • Data Export: Export timeline labels as TXT or package tagged frames as ZIP image packages

3. AI Art Studio (Powered by Gemini)

Section titled “3. AI Art Studio (Powered by Gemini)”

Intelligent Drawing

Section titled “Intelligent Drawing”

Uses the gemini-2.0-flash-exp model to transform multiple tagged frames into a cohesive, cute hand-drawn style storyboard.

Social Caption Generation

Section titled “Social Caption Generation”

Leverages gemini-2.0-flash-exp to automatically generate 3 different styles of viral copy:

  • Emotional Story: Engaging narrative-driven content
  • Tutorial Style: Practical how-to guides
  • Short & Punchy: Concise, impact-focused copy

Section titled “Character Fusion”

Section titled “Usage Workflow”

  1. Import Video: Copy Bilibili or Xiaohongshu share link (text included is fine), paste into the input box, click “Import Video”

  2. Mark Material: Use Space to control playback, ←/→ to adjust progress. When you see a highlight, click Tag button or press keyboard T key

  3. Enter AI Studio: After marking, click “Next: AI Drawing” at the bottom of the list on the right

  4. Create Content:

    • Paste your Gemini API Key in the upper right (if not configured in environment variables)
    • Creative Analysis: AI analyzes video steps
    • Image Generation: Generate hand-drawn storyboards, optionally fusing custom characters
    • Storyboard Refinement: HD redrawing of each frame (supports batch mode)
    • Copy & Cover: Generate social media copy and create matching covers

Ghostty Founder's Vibe Coding: A Conversational Journey with Claude

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Ghostty Founder’s Vibe Coding: A Conversational Journey with Claude

Section titled “Ghostty Founder’s Vibe Coding: A Conversational Journey with Claude”

When Mitchell Hashimoto, founder of Ghostty (the modern, GPU-accelerated terminal emulator), wanted to improve the macOS update feature, he didn’t just write code — he had a conversation. In a remarkable session he calls “vibe coding,” Mitchell paired with Claude to iteratively improve the codebase through dialogue, exploration, and shared discovery.

This isn’t about AI replacing developers. It’s about AI as a collaborative partner — and the transcript shows something beautiful: the AI catches things humans miss, the human provides direction and context, and together they build something better than either could alone.

What is “Vibe Coding”?

Section titled “What is “Vibe Coding”?”

Vibe coding is a conversational approach to software development where the developer and AI work together through natural dialogue. Rather than treating the AI as a command-execution tool, the developer treats it as a pair programmer — discussing, exploring, and iterating together.

In Mitchell’s session, captured from a real coding conversation on AmpCode, the flow goes like this:

  1. Oracle Consultation — Ask Claude to analyze code for improvements
  2. Discussion — Talk through the findings, make decisions together
  3. Implementation — Write code with Claude’s assistance
  4. Iteration — Learn from failures, adjust approach, try again
  5. Testing — Verify changes work, add tests for confidence

The Session: Improving Ghostty’s Update Feature

Section titled “The Session: Improving Ghostty’s Update Feature”

Mitchell started with a simple request: “Are there any other improvements you can see to be made with the @macos/Sources/Features/ Update feature? Don’t write any code. Consult the oracle.”

The “oracle” — Claude in analysis mode — identified several categories of improvements:

Critical Safety Issues

Section titled “Critical Safety Issues”
  1. Retain cycle in UpdateDriver.showUpdaterError — The retry closure captured self strongly, creating a memory leak
  2. Threading issues — UI-facing types should be marked @MainActor
  3. Progress value bugs — Progress values needed clamping to [0, 1] to prevent visual glitches
  4. Uncancellable timer — The “No Updates” auto-dismiss task could fire stale updates
  5. Swallowed errors — try? hid potential failures in startUpdater()

Areas Needing Unit Tests

Section titled “Areas Needing Unit Tests”
  1. ReleaseNotes parsing — Semver detection, git hash handling, edge cases
  2. UpdateState Equatable — Equality tests for downloading/error states
  3. ViewModel formatting — Text/icon/color mappings for each state
  4. Progress math — Division by zero, nil values, overshoot scenarios
  5. Auto-dismiss timing — Verify transitions and task cancellation

UX Improvements

Section titled “UX Improvements”
  • Add accessibility labels for assistive technologies
  • Clamp/abbreviate long error messages to prevent UI overflow

The Conversational Dance

Section titled “The Conversational Dance”

What makes this session remarkable is the back-and-forth:

Mitchell: “Stop stop stop. Undo all the main actor stuff.”

Claude: “Done! I’ve reverted all the @MainActor changes. The build now succeeds…”

Mitchell: “For the error message, instead of truncating, isn’t there a SwiftUI standard way to do this?”

Claude: “You’re absolutely right! SwiftUI has .lineLimit() and .truncationMode() for this…”

The human provides course correction when the AI goes down a problematic path. The AI suggests better approaches when the human asks questions. They learn from each other.

Key Improvements Made

Section titled “Key Improvements Made”

1. Fixed Retain Cycle

Section titled “1. Fixed Retain Cycle”

2. Clamped Progress Values

Section titled “2. Clamped Progress Values”

3. Made Auto-Dismiss Task Cancellable

Section titled “3. Made Auto-Dismiss Task Cancellable”

4. Added Accessibility Labels

Section titled “4. Added Accessibility Labels”

Simple, but critical — assistive technologies can now announce update status to visually impaired users.

5. Comprehensive Unit Tests

Section titled “5. Comprehensive Unit Tests”

The session added three new test files:

  • UpdateStateTests.swift — 150+ lines testing Equatable conformance for all states
  • UpdateViewModelTests.swift — 300+ lines testing formatting (text, icons, colors)
  • ProgressTests.swift — 150+ lines testing progress math edge cases

What This Session Teaches Us

Section titled “What This Session Teaches Us”

1. AI Sees Things Humans Miss

Section titled “1. AI Sees Things Humans Miss”

The oracle caught a retain cycle and progress value bugs that weren’t obvious. Code review tools often miss these too — having an AI analyze the code with fresh eyes catches different classes of issues.

2. Humans Provide Critical Judgment

Section titled “2. Humans Provide Critical Judgment”

When the AI suggested marking everything @MainActor, Mitchell recognized this would cause cascading compilation issues and asked to revert. Human judgment about architecture and trade-offs remains essential.

3. Iteration is Learning

Section titled “3. Iteration is Learning”

The session goes through multiple attempts:

  • First attempt at @MainActor fails → revert and try different approach
  • Manual error truncation → “isn’t there a SwiftUI standard way?” → use .truncationMode()

Each failure teaches something. The conversation enables rapid iteration.

4. Tests Provide Confidence

Section titled “4. Tests Provide Confidence”

The oracle suggested comprehensive unit tests. Writing tests alongside fixes ensures the improvements work correctly and prevents regressions.

5. Accessibility Shouldn’t Be an Afterthought

Section titled “5. Accessibility Shouldn’t Be an Afterthought”

The UX improvements weren’t flashy features — they were accessibility labels and proper text truncation. These make the software usable for everyone.

The Vibe Coding Workflow

Section titled “The Vibe Coding Workflow”

Based on Mitchell’s session, here’s a pattern for vibe coding:

  1. Ask, Don’t Command — “What improvements do you see?” vs “Fix this bug”
  2. Discuss Before Implementing — Talk through the findings, understand the why
  3. Implement Incrementally — Make one change at a time, verify it works
  4. Course Correct — Don’t be afraid to say “stop, undo that”
  5. Add Tests — Build confidence through test coverage
  6. Celebrate Learning — Each failure is a learning opportunity

Tools Used

Section titled “Tools Used”
  • Claude Code — AI pair programmer for the conversation
  • Swift/SwiftUI — Ghostty’s macOS frontend
  • Sparkle — macOS update framework
  • Swift Testing — Modern testing framework

Links

Section titled “Links”
  • Original Thread: AmpCode - Potential improvements for macos update feature
  • Ghostty: ghostty.org
  • Mitchell Hashimoto: @mitchellh on AmpCode

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Vibe coding isn’t about AI writing code for you. It’s about having a conversation with code — where the AI brings analytical superpowers, the human brings judgment and context, and together they create something better.

Mitchell’s session shows the future of programming: not humans replaced by AI, but humans augmented by AI — working together, learning from each other, and building better software through conversation.

The improvements to Ghostty’s update feature — safer code, better tests, improved accessibility — are a testament to what’s possible when developers embrace AI as a collaborative partner rather than a mere tool.

  • AI Development

  • Open Source
  • Ghostty

VoiceFlow: Free Local AI Voice Dictation That Never Sends Your Data to the Cloud

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction: Why Pay for Privacy Violation?

Section titled “Introduction: Why Pay for Privacy Violation?”

Cloud dictation services have become the norm, but they come with significant trade-offs: monthly subscription fees ($10-15/month), complete dependence on internet connectivity, and the uncomfortable reality that your voice data is processed on remote servers.

VoiceFlow by infiniV offers a compelling alternative. This open-source Windows application brings OpenAI’s powerful Whisper speech recognition model directly to your local machine. Every word you speak is processed entirely on your hardware—your voice data never leaves your device.

What is VoiceFlow?

Section titled “What is VoiceFlow?”

VoiceFlow is a free, open-source voice dictation application for Windows 10/11 that leverages OpenAI’s Whisper model for speech-to-text conversion. Unlike cloud-based alternatives, VoiceFlow runs 100% locally on your computer, ensuring complete privacy and eliminating ongoing costs.

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”
FeatureVoiceFlowCloud Services
Cost$0.00$10-15/mo
Data Privacy100% LocalCloud Processed
Offline SupportFull CapabilityNone
LatencyReal-timeNetwork Dependent
Account RequiredNoYes
Open SourceMIT LicenseProprietary

Technical Highlights

Section titled “Technical Highlights”
  • 16+ Whisper Models: Choose from Tiny (75MB) to Large-v3 (3GB), including Turbo models optimized for daily use
  • 99+ Language Support: Automatic language detection built-in
  • Custom Hotkeys: Configure shortcuts with Hold or Toggle recording modes
  • Local History: SQLite database stores searchable transcriptions locally
  • Auto-Paste: Text appears directly at your cursor—no copy-paste needed
  • GPU Support: Recent updates add GPU acceleration for faster inference

Privacy First Design

Section titled “Privacy First Design”

VoiceFlow’s architecture prioritizes privacy at every level:

  • Air-Gapped Safe: Works completely offline after initial model download
  • Open Source: Every line of code is auditable on GitHub
  • No Telemetry: Zero tracking, zero analytics, zero cloud calls
  • RAM-Only Processing: Microphone data never touches disk during processing

How VoiceFlow Works

Section titled “How VoiceFlow Works”

The application operates with elegant simplicity:

  1. Ready: VoiceFlow waits silently in your system tray with minimal presence
  2. Listening: Activate with your hotkey and speak naturally. Audio stays in RAM only with real-time amplitude visualization
  3. Transcribe & Paste: Release the hotkey. Local AI processes your audio instantly, then auto-pastes text at your cursor

Recording Modes

Section titled “Recording Modes”
  • Hold Mode: Hold to record, release to transcribe. Perfect for quick dictation bursts
  • Toggle Mode: Press once to start, press again to stop. Ideal for longer recordings

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”

VoiceFlow is ideal for:

  • Privacy-Conscious Professionals: Lawyers, doctors, and journalists handling sensitive information
  • Remote Workers: Needing reliable dictation without network dependency
  • Students: Lecture notes and study materials without subscription costs
  • Developers: Coding documentation and commit messages hands-free
  • Content Creators: Drafting articles and scripts without privacy concerns

Comparison with Alternatives

Section titled “Comparison with Alternatives”

vs. Cloud Services (Otter.ai, Whisper API)

Section titled “vs. Cloud Services (Otter.ai, Whisper API)”

VoiceFlow eliminates the monthly fees and removes any privacy concerns associated with cloud processing. You also get true offline capability.

vs. Other Local Whisper Implementations

Section titled “vs. Other Local Whisper Implementations”
  • winWhisper: VoiceFlow offers a more streamlined, always-ready experience with system tray integration
  • Buzz: VoiceFlow’s hotkey system and auto-paste provide smoother workflow integration
  • Whisper Desktop: VoiceFlow has a more modern UI with additional features like local history search

Precautions and Limitations

Section titled “Precautions and Limitations”
  • Platform: Currently Windows-only (10/11 64-bit)
  • Initial Download: First run requires downloading Whisper models (75MB - 3GB depending on model choice)
  • Hardware Requirements: Larger models may require more RAM and benefit from GPU acceleration
  • Language Accuracy: While 99+ languages are supported, accuracy varies by model size and language

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is VoiceFlow really free? A: Yes, completely free and open-source under the MIT License.

Q: Does it work offline? A: Yes, after the initial model download, it works completely offline.

Q: How accurate is the transcription? A: Accuracy depends on the model chosen. Large-v3 offers near-human accuracy, while Turbo provides the best speed-to-quality ratio for daily use.

Q: Can I use it for other languages? A: Yes, VoiceFlow supports 99+ languages with automatic detection.

Q: Does it store my voice recordings? A: No, microphone data is processed in RAM only and never stored. Only transcriptions are saved locally to the SQLite history database.

Future Development

Section titled “Future Development”

VoiceFlow is actively developed with recent updates including GPU support. Potential future enhancements may include:

  • Additional language model optimizations
  • Cross-platform support (macOS, Linux)
  • Advanced text processing features
  • Integration with other productivity tools

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

VoiceFlow represents a shift towards user-controlled AI tools. By bringing powerful speech recognition directly to your Windows machine without cloud dependencies or privacy trade-offs, it offers a compelling alternative to subscription-based cloud services.

Whether you’re a privacy advocate, a budget-conscious professional, or simply someone who values software independence, VoiceFlow delivers professional-grade voice dictation without the hidden costs.

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is JJYB_AI_VideoAutoCut free? A: Yes, completely free and open-source under MIT License.

Q: Does it work offline? A: Core video editing works offline. AI features require API connectivity, but pyttsx3 provides offline TTS fallback.

Q: What Python version is required? A: Python 3.9-3.11, with 3.10 being recommended for best compatibility.

Q: Can I use my own voice? A: Yes, the Voice Clone feature allows local voice cloning.

Q: How accurate is the video analysis? A: Depends on the vision model selected. GPT-4V and Claude Vision offer the best understanding.

Q: Can it handle batch processing? A: Yes, the remix mode supports batch video import and processing.

LLMTornado: The .NET Library to Build AI Agents with 25+ Built-in Connectors

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

LLMTornado: The .NET Library to Build AI Agents with 25+ Built-in Connectors

Section titled “LLMTornado: The .NET Library to Build AI Agents with 25+ Built-in Connectors”

Building AI agents and workflows typically requires integrating multiple APIs, handling different response formats, and managing provider-specific quirks. LLMTornado by lofcz simplifies this complexity with a unified .NET SDK that supports 25+ AI providers and vector databases out of the box.

What is LLMTornado?

Section titled “What is LLMTornado?”

LLMTornado is a provider-agnostic .NET SDK that empowers developers to build, orchestrate, and deploy AI agents and workflows. Whether you’re building a simple chatbot or an autonomous coding agent, LLM Tornado provides the tools you need with unparalleled integration into the AI ecosystem.

GitHub Repository: lofcz/LLMTornado Official Website: llmtornado.ai License: MIT NuGet Downloads: 70,000+ Language: C# / .NET

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Use Any Provider

Section titled “1. Use Any Provider”

Built-in connectors to 25+ AI providers with no dependencies on first-party SDKs:

Coordinate specialist agents with three core concepts:

  • Orchestrator (graph) - Define agent workflows
  • Runner (node) - Execute agent tasks
  • Advancer (edge) - Connect agents

Features include handoffs, parallel execution, Mermaid export, and builder pattern.

  • MCP (Model Context Protocol) - Connect agents to data sources and tools
  • A2A (Agent-to-Agent) - Enable collaboration between AI agents across platforms
  • Skills - Dynamically load folders of instructions and scripts for specialized tasks

Usage

Section titled “Usage”

Autonomous Runner (Recommended)

Section titled “Autonomous Runner (Recommended)”

The autonomous runner handles everything:

The runner:

  1. Checks all prerequisites (Claude CLI, Python, Git, etc.)
  2. Verifies skill installation
  3. Initializes the .loki/ directory
  4. Starts a status monitor (updates every 5 seconds)
  5. Starts Claude Code with live output
  6. Auto-resumes on rate limits or interruptions
  7. Continues until completion or max retries

Lovcode: Desktop Companion for Claude Code with Chat History & Configuration Management

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Lovcode: Desktop Companion for Claude Code

Section titled “Lovcode: Desktop Companion for Claude Code”

Claude Code has revolutionized AI-assisted development, but managing its extensive configuration files, chat history, and custom skills across multiple projects can be challenging. Enter Lovcode — a beautiful desktop companion application that brings all your Claude Code management needs into one unified interface.

What is Lovcode?

Section titled “What is Lovcode?”

Lovcode is a cross-platform desktop application built as a companion for AI coding tools, with primary focus on Claude Code. It provides a graphical interface to browse chat history, manage configurations, commands, skills, hooks, and more — all without touching the command line.

GitHub Repository: MarkShawn2020/lovcode Author: Mark Shawn (@markshawn2020) License: Apache-2.0 Platforms: macOS • Windows • Linux Latest Version: v0.19.0

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

Chat History Viewer

Section titled “Chat History Viewer”

Browse and search through all your Claude Code conversations across projects with full-text search capabilities. Quickly find past solutions, code snippets, or discussions without digging through JSON files.

Commands Manager

Section titled “Commands Manager”

View and manage all your slash commands from ~/.claude/commands/. Edit, create, and organize commands through a clean interface.

MCP Servers Configuration

Section titled “MCP Servers Configuration”

Configure and monitor Model Context Protocol (MCP) server integrations visually. Manage connections, settings, and status without editing configuration files.

Skills Management

Section titled “Skills Management”

Manage your reusable skill templates — install, configure, and organize skills from one place.

Hooks Automation

Section titled “Hooks Automation”

Configure automation triggers that execute at specific events during your Claude Code sessions.

Sub-Agents Control

Section titled “Sub-Agents Control”

Manage AI agents with custom models and configurations directly from the UI.

Output Styles

Section titled “Output Styles”

Customize response formatting and display preferences.

Marketplace

Section titled “Marketplace”

Browse and install community-contributed templates and configurations.

Lovcode fills an important gap in the Claude Code ecosystem by providing a polished desktop interface for managing all aspects of your AI coding assistant. Whether you’re a solo developer looking to organize your configurations or part of a team establishing standards, Lovcode offers the tools you need in a beautiful, performant package.

Download it today from GitHub Releases and take control of your Claude Code workflow.

Vibe Guide: Mastering AI Coding Agents for Maximum Productivity

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Vibe Guide: Mastering AI Coding Agents for Maximum Productivity

Section titled “Vibe Guide: Mastering AI Coding Agents for Maximum Productivity”

“This project is underrated. I’ve found it to be useful and fun” — Hamel Husain

“Biggest increase in productivity since Cursor” — Luke Harries

AI coding agents have transformed how developers work, but getting the most out of them requires more than just prompting. Based on the Vibe Kanban project, here’s a comprehensive guide to orchestrating AI coding agents effectively.

Planning: Always Start with a Plan

Section titled “Planning: Always Start with a Plan”

Five minutes spent planning saves ten minutes in review.

Regardless of task size, always begin with a plan. Whether your agent has a built-in “plan mode” or not, you can simply ask:

“Come up with a plan, confirm with me before making changes.”

Planning can feel like overhead, but it moves unavoidable work earlier. A plan is faster to judge than a diff.

Planning Sets the Shape

Section titled “Planning Sets the Shape”

Agents optimize for getting something working with minimal edits. Once that version exists, subsequent changes patch whatever’s there already—instead of rethinking the approach. The plan is your chance to pick the right shape before the code hardens around the wrong one.

Async Workflows: Juggle Multiple Threads

Section titled “Async Workflows: Juggle Multiple Threads”

Working asynchronously with coding agents (sometimes called “backgrounding”) lets you:

  • Juggle multiple threads at once
  • Avoid drifting into procrastination
  • Keep the agent running for longer stretches while you do other things

A typical workflow: keep the agent running continuously while you handle other tasks, checking in periodically.

Use YOLO Mode for True Async

Section titled “Use YOLO Mode for True Async”

Async only works if you’re not approving every tool call. Either use your agent’s YOLO mode, or give it an explicit allowlist of commands that covers almost everything it needs.

Otherwise you’ve reinvented pair programming—except slower.

Naming varies by platform: ‘yolo’, ‘dangerously skip permissions’, or similar.

Set Your Codebase Up to Be QA’d

Section titled “Set Your Codebase Up to Be QA’d”

If the agent can’t test its own changes, it’ll ask you to do it—which isn’t a great use of your time.

Put in the work to make changes verifiable with a dev or test command. Not everything is testable by an agent (frontend still needs human eyes), but most changes should end with “tests pass,” not “can you try this?”

Solve Dev Servers

Section titled “Solve Dev Servers”

Agents are bad at starting and cleaning up dev servers, which leads to:

  • Port conflicts
  • Wasted effort troubleshooting “something’s already running on that port” errors

Solutions like Dev Manager MCP assign ports and kill stale servers automatically.

Add Dummy Data for Offline Testing

Section titled “Add Dummy Data for Offline Testing”

Make it easy to run the project offline with realistic seed data. If the agent spends half its time getting the app into a testable state, you’ll get:

  • Flaky results
  • Slower progress

Dummy data also enables parallel agents—if they share a real database, one might work on a different schema version than another.

Combating Agent Laziness

Section titled “Combating Agent Laziness”

Coding agents make some lazy decisions repeatedly. Here’s what to watch for:

No Backwards Compatibility

Section titled “No Backwards Compatibility”

Every coding agent defaults to maintaining backwards compatibility. This is part overcaution, part laziness—keeping the old interface means not refactoring all call sites.

Add this to your system prompt:

We want the simplest change possible. We don’t care about migration. Code readability matters most, and we’re happy to make bigger changes to achieve it.

Disable Disabling Lint Rules

Section titled “Disable Disabling Lint Rules”

Agents love silencing linter errors instead of fixing them. eslint-disable-next-line and similar patterns appear across TypeScript, Rust, and likely other languages.

Ban this with plugins like eslint-comments/no-restricted-disable.

Frontend Best Practices

Section titled “Frontend Best Practices”

Separate Presentation from Logic

Section titled “Separate Presentation from Logic”

Keep leaf components presentational. Business logic (fetching data, etc.) lives in parent components.

Most frontend problems with agents involve Frankenstein components: thousands of lines of state management mixed with rendering. Separating concerns makes it easy to audit a presentational component’s props and spot irregularities.

It also helps the agent—agents look for patterns to follow. Clear folder structures give them distinct examples.

This can be semi-enforced via ESLint by disabling hooks like useState or useEffect in presentational components:

Restrict Tailwind

Section titled “Restrict Tailwind”

Agents love adding custom colors, spacing, and padding everywhere. Enforce a small set of allowed utility classes via ESLint. For example, p-4 and p-8 might be banned, but p-base and p-double are allowed and defined in your Tailwind config.

Use Figma MCP for Presentational Components

Section titled “Use Figma MCP for Presentational Components”

The Figma MCP server is excellent for a first pass at presentational components. Select a component in Figma, then prompt:

  • The component has been designed in Figma and can be retrieved using the Figma MCP server
  • All spacing, colors, and sizes should match existing Tailwind variables
  • We use [icon library]
  • If you cannot match an existing variable, ask the user what to do

Key Takeaways

Section titled “Key Takeaways”
PracticeBenefit
Always plan firstFaster to review plans than diffs
Use async workflowsJuggle multiple threads simultaneously
Enable YOLO modeTrue async, not slow pair programming
Make code QA-ableAgent can verify its own changes
Solve dev serversAvoid port conflicts and wasted time
Add dummy dataOffline testing + parallel agents
Break backwards compatibilityCleaner, more readable code
Enforce lint rulesFix root causes, don’t silence warnings
Separate concernsAvoid Frankenstein components
Use Figma MCPQuick presentational component passes

Getting Started with Vibe Kanban

Section titled “Getting Started with Vibe Kanban”

Vibe Kanban is an open-source project implementing these principles. Version 0.0.142 (released December 22, 2025) includes the latest features for AI coding agent orchestration.

The project is currently hiring—check out their careers page if you’re interested in building the future of AI-assisted development.

This guide is based on the official Vibe Guide from the Vibe Kanban project.

  • ai

Agentic Signal: Visual AI Workflow Automation Platform with Local LLM Integration

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Explore Agentic Signal by Code Forge Temple — a visual drag-and-drop AI workflow automation platform that runs entirely locally with Ollama integration. Build intelligent workflows without coding, with no cloud dependencies required.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Agentic Signal is an open-source visual AI workflow automation platform created by Code Forge Temple. It enables users to build intelligent, AI-powered workflows using a drag-and-drop interface while running everything locally on their machine.

What sets Agentic Signal apart is its commitment to privacy-first local execution. By integrating with Ollama, it allows you to harness the power of large language models without sending your data to the cloud. This makes it ideal for processing sensitive documents, building personal automation workflows, or simply maintaining full control over your AI interactions.

Repository: code-forge-temple/agentic-signal Website: agentic-signal.com

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”
FeatureDescription
Visual Drag-and-Drop InterfaceBuild workflows visually using React Flow — no coding required
Node-Based ArchitectureConnect data sources, AI processors, and outputs seamlessly
Real-time ExecutionSee your workflows run in real-time with live data flow visualization
Ollama IntegrationRun AI models locally with privacy and control
Tool CallingAI agents can execute functions and access external APIs
Structured OutputJSON schema validation for reliable AI responses
Conversation MemoryMaintain context across workflow executions
Browser AutomationWeb scraping and automation via Google Chrome integration

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Agentic Signal provides pre-built releases for Windows, macOS, and Linux:

  1. Download the release package for your operating system from GitHub Releases

  2. Install Google Chrome — required for web scraping and browser automation nodes

  3. Install and Run Agentic Signal

    • Run the installer and follow the prompts
    • Windows users: When launching for the first time, your antivirus may scan the app (the installer is unsigned)

  4. Configure Ollama

    • Make sure Ollama is running with CORS enabled for the Windows app
    • Configure the Ollama Host in app settings

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Required

Section titled “Required”

  • Google Chrome — Required for browser automation and web scraping nodes

    • Download from google.com/chrome

  • Ollama — Local LLM runtime

Optional (for Google Services Integration)

Section titled “Optional (for Google Services Integration)”

If you want to use Gmail, Google Drive, or Google Calendar nodes, you’ll need to set up OAuth2 credentials:

  1. Go to Google Cloud Console
  2. Create a new project or select existing one
  3. Enable the APIs you want to use (Gmail, Drive, Calendar)
  4. Create OAuth 2.0 credentials (Desktop app)
  5. Download the credentials JSON file

Node Types and Architecture

Section titled “Node Types and Architecture”

Agentic Signal uses a node-based workflow architecture where each node represents a processing unit:

Node Structure

Section titled “Node Structure”
  • Input/Output Data Connectors — Connect data flow between nodes
  • Tool Connector — Additional connectors for AI tools and functions
  • Timer Connector — Schedule automatic execution at intervals
  • Settings — Configure node-specific options
  • Error Logs — View errors when processing fails
  • Output — View processed results
  • Run — Manually trigger workflow execution

Available Node Types

Section titled “Available Node Types”
Node TypeDescription
Data SourceInput data from files, APIs, or manual entry
AI Data ProcessingProcess data with local LLMs via Ollama
AI ToolExecute function calling with AI agents
HTTP DataMake REST API calls to external services
JSON ReformatterTransform and restructure JSON data
ChartVisualize data with various chart types
Data ValidationValidate data against schemas
Data Flow SpyDebug and inspect data flow
Timer NodeSchedule periodic executions

Agentic Signal supports a growing list of integrations:

IntegrationDescription

Date/Time ToolsGet current date and time

  • Web scraping capabilities

Daily Workflow Examples

Section titled “Daily Workflow Examples”

Example 1: AI-Powered Email Assistant

Section titled “Example 1: AI-Powered Email Assistant”

Create a workflow that:

  1. Fetches new emails from Gmail (Data Source → Gmail)
  2. Uses local LLM to categorize and prioritize (AI Data Processing)
  3. Generates summary responses (AI Tool)
  4. Saves to Google Drive for reference (HTTP Data)

Example 2: Research Automation

Section titled “Example 2: Research Automation”

Build a workflow that:

  1. Takes a research topic as input (Data Source)
  2. Searches multiple sources (DuckDuckGo, Brave Search nodes)
  3. Extracts and summarizes findings with local LLM (AI Data Processing)
  4. Formats results into a structured report (JSON Reformatter)
  5. Saves to file or sends to email (Output node)

Example 3: Weather-Based Notifications

Section titled “Example 3: Weather-Based Notifications”

Create a daily automation:

  1. Trigger at 7 AM daily (Timer Node)
  2. Fetch weather data for your location (Weather API)
  3. Generate personalized recommendation with local LLM (AI Data Processing)
  4. Display formatted output (Chart or Display node)

  • Windows: C:\Program Files\Google\Chrome\Application\chrome.exe
  • macOS: /Applications/Google Chrome.app/Contents/MacOS/Google Chrome
  • Linux: /usr/bin/google-chrome

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

App Won’t Start (Windows)

Section titled “App Won’t Start (Windows)”

If the app is slow or unresponsive on first launch:

  1. Wait for antivirus scan to complete
  2. Close and restart Agentic Signal
  3. Add exception to antivirus if needed

Ollama Connection Failed

Section titled “Ollama Connection Failed”
  1. Verify Ollama is running: ollama list
  2. Check CORS is enabled: OLLAMA_ORIGINS="*" ollama serve
  3. Verify Ollama Host in app settings is http://localhost:11434

Browser Automation Not Working

Section titled “Browser Automation Not Working”
  1. Verify Chrome is installed
  2. Check Chrome executable path in app settings
  3. Make sure Chrome version is up-to-date

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Start Simple — Begin with basic workflows before adding complexity
  2. Use Appropriate Models — Choose Ollama models based on your task (faster models for simple tasks, more capable for complex reasoning)
  3. Modular Design — Break complex workflows into smaller, reusable components
  4. Test Iteratively — Run and test each node as you build
  5. Monitor Performance — Use Data Flow Spy to debug bottlenecks

Awesome CEO: A Curated Resource Guide for Startup Founders

Section titled “Awesome CEO: A Curated Resource Guide for Startup Founders”

Being a CEO or founder of a high-growth startup is one of the most challenging roles anyone can take on. You’re expected to be a visionary, a manager, a fundraiser, a product expert, and a culture leader—all at the same time. Fortunately, you don’t have to figure it all out on your own.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Awesome CEO is a curated and opinionated collection of resources specifically designed for startup founders and leaders navigating the high-growth journey. Created by Dima (who introduces himself with the humble greeting “Hello, my name is Dima and I’m a CEO”), this repository has become a go-to reference for entrepreneurs worldwide.

In this article, we’ll explore the key categories and insights from this invaluable resource, helping you discover the tools and knowledge that can accelerate your entrepreneurial journey.

Why This Resource Matters

Section titled “Why This Resource Matters”

The startup ecosystem is flooded with advice, blog posts, and “expert” opinions. What makes Awesome CEO different is its curation—every resource has been hand-picked for its practical value, not its popularity. The collection spans the entire founder journey from idea to IPO.

  • Dropbox’s Startup Fundraising Playbook—Real tactics from a company that’s been there
  • Khosla Ventures on Pre-Launch Fundraising—How to raise before you even have a product

Critical Insight: The hardest question at pre-seed and seed stage isn’t “how do I raise?” but “should I persist on this idea or move to the next one?” This framework for decision-making alone is worth the price of admission.

Claude Code Transcripts: Publish Your AI Coding Sessions as HTML

Dec 28, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Claude Code Transcripts: Publish Your AI Coding Sessions as HTML

Section titled “Claude Code Transcripts: Publish Your AI Coding Sessions as HTML”

When using Claude Code for software development, every session contains valuable insights — debugging approaches, architectural decisions, and problem-solving techniques. But these conversations are locked away in JSON files buried in ~/.claude/projects.

Simon Willison has released claude-code-transcripts, a Python CLI tool that converts these session files into beautiful, browsable HTML transcripts that can be shared with others.

What is claude-code-transcripts?

Section titled “What is claude-code-transcripts?”

claude-code-transcripts is a command-line tool that converts Claude Code session data (stored as JSON or JSONL files) into paginated, mobile-friendly HTML transcripts. It provides:

  • Better readability than the raw Claude Code interface
  • Shareable output that works with any static hosting or GitHub Gists
  • Multiple input sources: local sessions, web sessions via API, or direct JSON files
  • Clean, organized layout with pagination for long sessions

GitHub Repository: simonw/claude-code-transcripts Author: Simon Willison License: Apache 2.0 PyPI: claude-code-transcripts

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

The tool can be installed using uv (recommended) or run directly without installation:

Four Main Commands

Section titled “Four Main Commands”

The tool provides four commands for different use cases:

1. local (default) - Browse Local Sessions

Section titled “1. local (default) - Browse Local Sessions”

Convert sessions stored locally in ~/.claude/projects:

2. web - Import from Claude API

Section titled “2. web - Import from Claude API”

Fetch sessions directly from the Claude web API:

On macOS, credentials are automatically retrieved from your keychain. On other platforms, use --token and --org-uuid.

3. json - Convert Specific Files

Section titled “3. json - Convert Specific Files”

Convert a JSON or JSONL session file directly:

4. all - Archive All Sessions

Section titled “4. all - Archive All Sessions”

Convert all local sessions into a browsable HTML archive:

This creates a directory structure with:

  • A master index listing all projects
  • Per-project pages listing sessions
  • Individual session transcripts

Output Options

Section titled “Output Options”

All commands support these useful options:

OptionDescription
-o, --output DIROutput directory (default: temp dir + open browser)
-a, --output-autoAuto-name subdirectory based on session ID
--repo OWNER/NAMEGitHub repo for commit links
--openOpen generated HTML in default browser
--gistUpload to GitHub Gist and return preview URL
--jsonInclude original session file in output

Publishing to GitHub Gist

Section titled “Publishing to GitHub Gist”

One of the most powerful features is the --gist option:

This requires the GitHub CLI to be installed and authenticated. The output includes:

Example Output

Section titled “Example Output”

The tool generates:

  • index.html - Timeline page with prompts and commits
  • page-001.html, page-002.html, etc. - Paginated transcript pages

See an example transcript created by Simon.

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”
  1. Documentation - Turn complex debugging sessions into reference documentation
  2. Knowledge Sharing - Share architectural decisions with your team
  3. Tutorials - Create step-by-step guides from real coding sessions
  4. Archiving - Build a searchable archive of your development work
  5. Blogging - Transform interesting sessions into blog posts

Technical Details

Section titled “Technical Details”
  • Input Sources: Local ~/.claude/projects, Claude Web API, or JSON/JSONL files
  • Output Format: Static HTML with CSS, no build step required
  • Dependencies: Python 3.8+, minimal dependencies
  • Platform Support: macOS, Linux, Windows

Comparison with Alternatives

Section titled “Comparison with Alternatives”
Featureclaude-code-transcriptsclaude-notes
GitHub Gist integration✅ Built-in❌ No
Web API support✅ Yes❌ Local only
Archive all sessions✅ Yes❌ Per-file only
Mobile-friendly✅ Yes✅ Yes
Pagination✅ Yes✅ Yes

Both tools serve similar purposes, but claude-code-transcripts offers more advanced features for sharing and publishing.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

claude-code-transcripts fills an important gap in the Claude Code ecosystem by making sessions shareable and readable outside the Claude Code interface. Whether you’re documenting your work, sharing with colleagues, or building a knowledge base, this tool transforms ephemeral AI conversations into permanent, valuable resources.

Happy Claude Skills: Practical Plugin Collection for Claude Code

Section titled “Happy Claude Skills: Practical Plugin Collection for Claude Code”

Claude Code’s plugin system allows developers to extend its capabilities with custom skills. While the official marketplace is growing, the community has already started creating useful plugins. One such contribution is happy-claude-skills by iamzhihuix, a collection of three practical skills for common productivity tasks.

What is happy-claude-skills?

Section titled “What is happy-claude-skills?”

happy-claude-skills is an open-source collection of skill plugins designed for Claude Code. It currently includes three skills:

  1. docx-format-replicator - Extract and replicate Word document formatting
  2. video-processor - Download and process videos from YouTube and other platforms
  3. wechat-article-writer - Automated WeChat article writing workflow

GitHub Repository: iamzhihuix/happy-claude-skills Author: iamzhihuix License: MIT

Section titled “Method 1: Plugin Marketplace (Recommended)”

Then install individual skills:
